The 1567 New Testament is the product of the work of three translators: Thomas Huet, dean of St David's (Revelation), Bishop Richard Davies (1 Timothy, Hebrews, James, 1 Peter, 2 Peter), and William Salesbury (the rest, plus 'arguments' and marginal notes etc.). Huet's translation of Revelation differs markedly in dialect and style from that of the other two translators, and, for this reason, the New Testament translation has been treated, essentially, as three texts, with two of them (the work of Salesbury and Huet) represented in the corpus. The transcription of Salesbury's work contains three extracts from across the New Testament: one Gospel passage (Matthew 26-28), a passage from Acts 24-8, and a more discursive extract from 2 Corinthians 1-9.
The text used a different font to distinguish 'inserted words' (geiriau dodi), that is, words not present in the Greek that were added to improve the sense of the Welsh, and for variant forms (often forms in different dialects). This often results in part of a word appearing in a font different from that of the rest of the word. For instance <diernot> may be read as die (that is, diau) or as diernot (that is, diwrnod)
Salesbury used a nonstandard orthography for certain words in his text, with the aim of maximising similarities (whether genetic or through borrowing) between Welsh and Latin. For instance, egwlys ‘church’ is spelled <eccles>. No attempt has been made here to provide markup for these unusual spellings, and, hence, in the concordance, such item appear only under Salesbury's spelling form.

Eb law hyny y mae pop gair a dybiwyt y vot yn andeallus, ai o ran llediaith y 'wlat, ai o ancynefinder y devnydd, wedy ei noti ai eglurhau ar 'ledemyl y tu dalen gydrychiol.

Verse numbers are not marked in the original. The relevant numbers have been supplied in the markup, within the seg-element, and are displayed in the output files for ease of reference. Direct speech and other quotations are not explicitly marked in the original either, but have been tagged using the q-element in the transcription. For details of the structural markup for chapters and verses, see the notes to the 1588 Bible.
The text includes extensive marginal glosses of a linguistic nature. In the transcription, the word or phrase glossed is marked up using the term-element, and the gloss itself immediately follows, marked up using the gloss-element. Note that although the glosses are placed within the line in the transcription, that are always marginal glosses in the original. In the output files, glosses have been placed in square brackets, and the terms to which they apply are underlined.
In cases where words or parts of words are written in a different font to indicate that the word may be read in its entirety, or with the extra letters omitted (see above), the transcription tags the words or letters marked out in this way using the hi-element with the rend-attribute "antiqua" (for instance, the example mentioned above is represented as die<hi rend="antiqua">rnot</hi>.
The text contains three special characters: hooked l (for <ll>), eth (ð) (for <dd>) and a double v (vv) (for <w>). These are represented in the TEI-transcription using the character entities &lhook;, ð and &vv; respectively. In the diplomatic files, they are represented more or less in the form they are found in the original. For indexing purposes, they are replaced with their modern equivalents.
